{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3289149,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-19T18:08:46.948Z","cooked":"

Only one note at a time…

Normally teams toss relatively thin polycarbonate shields on robots, which works great for deflecting balls. With a little shaking around you can normally get a stuck ball out of a bot.

With the notes it’s a little different, a note stuck over a swerve drive is basically game over (at least for scoring). Missed notes into the speaker, amp, from the source, or even shooting into the trap all run the risk of getting snagged on your bot.

Has your team give any thoughts when designing to limit these catch points?

Only a little bit, making a giant pyramid of polycarb to let notes slide down. Dependant on robot design though.

Skyehawk:

a note stuck over a swerve drive

Imagine a note stuck over a climber, ring-toss style. Instant game over, go play defense. It’ll be interesting to see if this becomes an issue, and if teams who expected it to will have ways to deal with it.
